title: Record level access control
content:
The Access control tab in Studio offers an Enable Record Level Access Control (RLAC) option that enables a tenant admin to implement record level access control for agent users. For example, the tenant admin can configure RLAC for Request to allow only the assignee and assignment group to access a request. 

Currently, this feature supports only View access control at the record level. For Create, Update, and Delete access control, you can use business rules.
RLAC is designed mainly for agent users and has no impact on Service Portal users except in some customization use cases. For a comparison of RLAC and other data access control tools such as data domain segmentation and entitlement rules, see Service Management data access control tools.

RLAC overview

This section explains how RLAC works and describes its limitations.  

Supported record types

The Access control tab in Studio is available for most out-of-the-box record types and all custom record types.

Unsupported record types include Person, Group, Entitlement Rule, Notification History Event, Aviator Model, Cost allocation, Fulfillment Plan, External system, External reference, and more master data types.

Out of the box, the RLAC feature is disabled for all supported record types. 

If enabled, RLAC takes effect on both UI operations and API calls. Here is a list of UI operations where RLAC takes effect:

  • Viewing grids  

  • Viewing forms  

  • Viewing dashboards and reports

  • IDOL search

RLAC handling for main or parent records

There are cases where a user has no access to a record, but has access to the main record or parent record of that record. In these cases, the system behaves as follows. 

Main records

Once RLAC is enabled on the main record type, the system enforces the access control on grids, forms, dashboards, EMS API calls, and more of the main records. However, when it comes to Entity Link fields and M2M fields, the system behaves as follows:

  • Entity Link fields: The system bypasses RLAC for ENTITY_LINK fields on grids and forms of a main record. If a user has access to the main record, the user can view the existing ENTITY_LINK field value in the main record. For example, if a user has access to a request record but has no access to the service in the request record according to the RLAC configuration for Actual Service, the user can still see the service value in the request record, but can't open the Actual Service record.
    When the user adds an Entity_Link.Property column to a grid view, the system usually displays that column as empty, unless the property is ID or Display Label. The user needs to drill down to the details and view the other properties of the Entity Link record if the user has access to that record.
    For API requests to the main record with Entity_Link.Property in the layout, if RLAC is enabled on that linked record type, the system may skip Entity_Link.Property. To obtain those properties, the user needs to send another API request to that linked record instead of through the main record.
  • M2M fields: The system doesn't bypass RLAC for M2M fields on the grids and forms of the main record. For example, a Request record has three related incidents, and the user has access to only two of them according to the RLAC configuration for Incident. In this case, the user will see only two related incidents in the Request record. 

Parent record preview

If an agent user is the assignee of a task, a member of the assignment group of a task, or a delegate of an approval task, the user can still view the parent record of the task in the Preview pane, even if the user has no access to the parent record according to the RLAC configuration.

However, if the user drills down to the parent record details, the system still checks the RLAC filter for the current user.

Supported field types in the RLAC filter

Once the Enable Record Level Access Control (RLAC) option is enabled, you can select the following types of fields as a filter to control user access to records:

  • ENTITY_LINK 
  • ENTITY_LINK.ENTITY_LINK 

These fields must have a reference to Person or Group in Studio.

The following table gives some examples of the Request record type. 

Field  Field type RLAC description
Assignee ENTITY_LINK Allows access to records where the current user is the assignee.
Assignment Group ENTITY_LINK Allows access to records where the current user is a member of the assignment group.
Service.Owner ENTITY_LINK.ENTITY_LINK Allows access to records where the current user is the owner of the services in those records.

Using indexed fields for optimal performance

For performance considerations, we recommend that you use indexed fields for RLAC to increase the search speed of the system. 

This is required only when your access filter uses an ENTITY_LINK.ENTITY_LINK field. In this case, contact your database administrator to add an index for each of the access filter fields (not only the ENTITY_LINK.ENTITY_LINK field). 

 For details, see Create an index for the field with the B-tree engine.

RLAC limitations

  • If RLAC is enabled for a record type, when users set an entity link field as the "group by" field for a grid view of that record type, the Related button is hidden for that entity link field. For example, if RLAC is enabled for Actual Service, when you set the Service field as the "group by" field for a Request grid, the Related button is hidden for the Service field. 
  • If you configure RLAC for the Device record type by specifying "Owner" as the access filter field, users who aren't owners of a device can still view its details through the CI detection functionality (by hovering over the device name if it is included in the description of records).
  • If agent user B views an operational report or an operational raw data report in less than 20 minutes after user A views the same report, user B sees the same report data as user A and may see an error when trying to drill down the records. If this happens, user B can update a field such as the Sort By field to refresh the report. 
  • This feature doesn't control access to articles and offerings returned by a semantic search offered by Aviator.
  • When OData retrieves the history data of a record, it ignores the RLAC configuration for the record type. 
  • RLAC configurations don't take effect on Change Analytics, Hot Topic Analytics, and business rule execution. 

Configure record level access control

Configure RLAC for a record type by specifying access filter fields. Once RLAC is configured, you may want to let certain users bypass RLAC. 

Configure access control fields

  • If you're going to configure an ENTITY_LINK.ENTITY_LINK field for RLAC, before you begin, make sure you have added an index for that field. See the "Using indexed fields for optimal performance" section in this.
  •  It is recommended to have the user member of only a few hundred groups (not more than 500 user groups) to ensure optimal performance for data retrieval when the access filter is referenced to a group to view the records assigned to the groups the currently logged-in user is a member of.

The following steps use the Request record type as an example. The process for other record types is the same. 

  1. Log in to the agent interface as the tenant admin.
  2. Navigate to Administration > Configuration > Studio.
  3. Open the Request record type, and click the Access control tab.
  4. Select the Enable Record Level Access Control (RLAC) check box. The system expands the View section.
  5. Configure fields in the View section, as described below.
    To add an ENTITY_LINK field, click Add Field, and then select the field from the dropdown list.
    To add an ENTITY_LINK.ENTITY_LINK field, click Add Field to select the first field from the dropdown list, and then click Related to select a field from the second dropdown list. 
    You can click Add Field repeatedly to add more fields or click Remove next to a field to remove it.
    You can select a maximum of 5 fields as an access filter. Among them, you can have no more than one ENTITY_LINK.ENTITY_LINK field. 
  6. Click Save. 
    To discard your changes, click Discard instead.

Configure users to bypass RLAC

After you have configured RLAC, it takes effect for all agent users except tenant administrators. You may want to allow some other users to bypass the RLAC configuration:

  • According to your business needs, some agent users need to bypass the RLAC configuration.
  • If a record type has an associated integration, we recommend allowing the dedicated integration user to bypass the RLAC configuration for that record type. If you are using OData for a BI integration, you also need to review the integration user and decide whether to grant them permission to bypass the RLAC configuration.

To do this, go to Administration > Master Data > People > Roles, and assign the Access Control Override role permission for that record type to the agent user or integration user.
